content: Omigod, a media figure engaged in hyperbole to (successfully, in this case) attract attention, stop the presses! Nolte is right on the merits though — like most representative democracies, our political system is based on the concept of opposition which in turn leads to a reliance on polemical rhetoric. And, virtue-signalling aside, anyone with any familiarity with polemics knows that exaggeration is a useful tool in advancing arguments (Newsflash: When the teachers’ unions or other public ed lobbyists claim that their only concern is for ‘the kids’, they’re not telling the complete truth). And if someone really wants to see an example of lying in the pursuit of a political goal, look up Ben Rhodes and his account of the tactics the Obama Administration used to sell the Iran Nuclear Deal — a deception far more calculated and systematic than anything Trump has tried to date.
